title: Quickstart Guide
text: opal R package building fast, transparent, reproducible stock assessment models. leverages RTMB automatic differentiation, enabling efficient optimization uncertainty quantification. core workflow involves: Specifying model — Define population dynamics, selectivity, biological parameters, data likelihoods Running optimization — Fit model data estimate key parameters See vignette("bet") detailed worked example.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Darcy Webber. Author. Philipp Neubauer. Author. Nicholas Ducharme-Barth. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Webber D, Neubauer P, Ducharme-Barth N (2026). opal: open population assessment library. R package version 0.0.1, https://n-ducharmebarth-noaa.github.io/opal/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {opal: The open population assessment library},   author = {Darcy Webber and Philipp Neubauer and Nicholas Ducharme-Barth},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.0.1},   url = {https://n-ducharmebarth-noaa.github.io/opal/}, }

title: The open population assessment library
text: opal open population assessment library — fast, flexible, modern R package fisheries stock assessment. Built RTMB, opal provides powerful framework conducting quantitative population dynamics modeling stock assessment analyses.

title: The open population assessment library
text: Fast: Leverages RTMB’s efficient automatic differentiation optimization engine rapid model fitting sensitivity analyses Flexible: Modular design allows users construct custom population models combining readily available custom process components Modern: Built contemporary R programming patterns, extensive testing, well-documented functions reproducible, transparent science Open & Accessible: Released open-source license clear documentation; transforms complex stock assessment workflows intuitive R functions, reducing barriers entry enabling collaborative development

title: The open population assessment library
text: opal designed fisheries scientists, stock assessment analysts, population modeling researchers need transparent, reproducible, collaborative framework quantitative population assessment. Whether ’re building novel models, conducting sensitivity analyses, sharing transparent workflows colleagues, opal provides tools infrastructure make rigorous stock assessment accessible reproducible.

title: The open population assessment library
text: can install development version opal GitHub: Ensure RTMB installed:

title: The open population assessment library
code: library(opal)  # Build a basic population model # (Example code will depend on your API—update with actual function calls)

title: The open population assessment library
text: opal provides tools : Population dynamics: Model age/size structure, vital rates, stock-recruitment relationships Parameter estimation: Fit models fisheries data (catch, surveys, length compositions, etc.) Inference: Conduct Bayesian frequentist analyses uncertainty quantification Diagnostics: Evaluate model fit residuals, retrospective analyses, likelihood profiling Projections: Forecast population dynamics different management scenarios

title: The open population assessment library
text: detailed examples function reference, see vignettes inline function documentation (?opal).

title: The open population assessment library
text: Contributions welcome. Please open issue submit pull request enhancements bug fixes.

title: The open population assessment library
text: opal uses standard development workflow: main: Stable release branch. Code represents tested, production-ready versions package. dev: Active development branch. New features, bug fixes, improvements developed tested merged main. Workflow: Submit pull requests dev branch. features tested validated, incorporated main release.

title: The open population assessment library
text: See LICENSE terms conditions.

title: The open population assessment library
text: use opal research, please cite appropriately. Details provided package matures.

what: Convert RTMB real-line selectivity parameters back to SS3 natural scale — convert_rtmb_selex_to_ss3
title: Convert RTMB real-line selectivity parameters back to SS3 natural scale — convert_rtmb_selex_to_ss3
text: Inverse convert_ss3_selex_to_rtmb. Useful verifying round-trip conversion reporting parameter values natural units.

title: Convert RTMB real-line selectivity parameters back to SS3 natural scale — convert_rtmb_selex_to_ss3
Convert RTMB real-line selectivity parameters back to SS3 natural scale — convert_rtmb_selex_to_ss3
text: par_sel Numeric matrix [n_fishery, 6] RTMB real-line parameters. sel_type_f Integer vector (1 = logistic, 2 = double-normal). sel_lengths Numeric vector selectivity length-bin midpoints.

title: Convert RTMB real-line selectivity parameters back to SS3 natural scale — convert_rtmb_selex_to_ss3
text: Data.frame SS3-scale parameter values per fishery.

what: Convert SS3 selectivity parameters to RTMB real-line parameterization — convert_ss3_selex_to_rtmb
title: Convert SS3 selectivity parameters to RTMB real-line parameterization — convert_ss3_selex_to_rtmb
text: Takes SS3 natural-scale selectivity parameters converts centered real-line parameterization used RTMB sel_logistic sel_double_normal functions.

title: Convert SS3 selectivity parameters to RTMB real-line parameterization — convert_ss3_selex_to_rtmb
Convert SS3 selectivity parameters to RTMB real-line parameterization — convert_ss3_selex_to_rtmb
text: ss3_pars data.frame matrix one row per fishery. double-normal (pattern 24): columns peak, top_logit, ascend_se, descend_se, start_logit, end_logit. logistic (pattern 1): columns inflection, width. sel_type_f Integer vector (length n_fishery). 1 = logistic, 2 = double-normal. sel_lengths Numeric vector selectivity length-bin midpoints (vector passed sel_logistic/sel_double_normal).

title: Convert SS3 selectivity parameters to RTMB real-line parameterization — convert_ss3_selex_to_rtmb
text: Numeric matrix [n_fishery, 6] RTMB real-line parameters.

title: Population dynamics — do_dynamics
text: Runs core age- season-structured population dynamics loop bigeye tuna. Starts initial equilibrium numbers (derived B0 h), applies seasonal harvest, natural mortality, spawning, recruitment (Beverton-Holt log-normal deviates), computes predicted catches harvest rates.

title: Population dynamics — do_dynamics
code: do_dynamics(   data,   parameters,   B0,   R0,   alpha,   beta,   h = 0.95,   sigma_r = 0.6,   M_a,   maturity_a,   weight_fya,   init_number_a,   sel_fya )

title: Population dynamics — do_dynamics
text: data list model data.  Must contain minimum: first_yr, first_yr_catch, n_year, n_season, n_fishery, n_age, catch_obs_ysf, catch_units_f. parameters list model parameters.  Must contain minimum: rdev_y. B0 Numeric. Unfished equilibrium spawning biomass. R0 Numeric. Unfished equilibrium recruitment. alpha Numeric. Beverton-Holt stock-recruitment alpha parameter. beta Numeric. Beverton-Holt stock-recruitment beta parameter. h Numeric (0.2–1). Steepness Beverton-Holt stock-recruitment relationship. sigma_r Numeric > 0. Standard deviation log recruitment deviations. M_a Numeric vector length n_age. Natural mortality age. Passed explicitly AD gradients propagate M ever estimated. maturity_a Numeric vector length n_age. Maturity age. Passed explicitly AD gradients propagate growth ever estimated. weight_fya Numeric array [n_fishery, n_year, n_age]. Mean weight age fishery year.  Passed explicitly AD gradients propagate growth ever estimated. init_number_a Numeric vector length n_age. Initial equilibrium numbers--age (get_initial_numbers). sel_fya Numeric array [n_fishery, n_year, n_age]. Fishery-specific selectivity age year (get_selectivity).

title: Population dynamics — do_dynamics
text: named list : number_ysa Numbers--age array [n_year+1, n_season, n_age]. lp_penalty Total penalty posfun (harvest rate constraints).

title: Population dynamics — do_dynamics
text: derived biology arrays (M_a, maturity_a, weight_fya) passed explicit arguments rather read data. ensures AD gradients propagate correctly quantities carry estimated parameters future (e.g., growth parameters estimated via PLA, natural mortality via Lorenzen equation).

title: Evaluate priors — evaluate_priors
text: Evaluate priors

title: Evaluate priors — evaluate_priors
text: parameters list specifying parameters passed MakeADFun. Can generated using get_parameters() function. priors list named lists specifying priors parameters. Can generated using get_priors() function.

title: Evaluate priors — evaluate_priors
text: numeric value.

title: Evaluate priors — evaluate_priors
code: parameters <- list(par_log_m4 = log(0.167)) priors <- list(   par_log_m4 = list(type = "normal", par1 = log(0.12), par2 = 0.4,                      index = which("par_log_m4" == names(parameters))) ) evaluate_priors(parameters, priors) #> [1] 0.3439966

title: Natural mortality at age — get_M
text: min_age minimum model age. max_age maximum model age. age_increase_M age M begins increase . m0 M age-1 2. m4 M age-4 (controls slope decline). m10 M age-10 (base flat zone). m30 M age-30 (terminal age M).

title: Natural mortality at age — get_M
text: vector M age.

title: Natural mortality at length — get_M_length
text: vector M age.

Season index (1-based). number_ysa Numeric array [n_year+1, n_season, n_age]. Current numbers--age. sel_fya Numeric array [n_fishery, n_year, n_age]. Selectivity age fishery year. weight_fya Numeric array [n_fishery, n_year, n_age]. Mean weight age fishery year.  Passed explicitly AD gradients propagate growth ever estimated.

what: Compute selectivity-at-age from length-based selectivity curves — get_selectivity

title: Compute selectivity-at-age from length-based selectivity curves — get_selectivity
text: data list containing model data. Required elements: n_fishery, n_year, n_age, sel_type_f. par_sel Numeric matrix dimensions [n_fishery, 6]. row real-line parameter vector. logistic (sel_type_f == 1), columns 1:2 used. double-normal (sel_type_f == 2), 6 used. mu_a Numeric vector (length n_age) mean length age. May AD growth parameters estimated. sd_a Numeric vector (length n_age) SD length age. May AD growth parameters estimated. len_lower Numeric vector (length n_len) lower bounds length bins.  Derived internally len_bin_start, len_bin_width, n_len inside bet_model(). len_upper Numeric vector (length n_len) upper bounds length bins. len_mid Numeric vector (length n_len) length-bin midpoints.

title: Compute selectivity-at-age from length-based selectivity curves — get_selectivity
text: 3D array sel_fya dimensions [n_fishery, n_year, n_age].

title: Compute selectivity-at-age from length-based selectivity curves — get_selectivity
text: PLA computed internally mu_a sd_a AD gradients propagate correctly growth parameters estimated future. Selectivity currently time-invariant within fishery (constant across years).

title: Resolve a biology vector to age-basis — resolve_bio_vector
text: vector length matches n_age, returned unchanged (assumed already age basis).  vector length matches n_len (n_len != n_age), converted age using probability--length--age matrix: vec_a = t(pla) %*% vec_l. Otherwise informative error thrown.

Resolve a biology vector to age-basis — resolve_bio_vector

what: Double-normal selectivity as a function of length (SS3 pattern 24, full form) — sel_double_normal
title: Double-normal selectivity as a function of length (SS3 pattern 24, full form) — sel_double_normal
text: parameters real line, making parameterization suitable unconstrained optimization AD. length-bin vector x used define natural scales position width parameters.

title: Double-normal selectivity as a function of length (SS3 pattern 24, full form) — sel_double_normal
Double-normal selectivity as a function of length (SS3 pattern 24, full form) — sel_double_normal
text: x Numeric vector length-bin midpoints. par Numeric vector length 6 containing selectivity parameters. par[1] () Peak location (real line). Transformed via mean(x) + * sd(x), = 0 places peak mean(x). par[2] (b) Plateau width (real line). Controls distance peak start descending limb via logistic transform available range: peak + bin_width + (0.99 * max(x) - peak - bin_width) / (1 + exp(-b)). par[3] (c) Ascending width (real line, log-space). Actual width = exp(c) * sd(x). c = 0 gives ascending width equal sd(x). par[4] (d) Descending width (real line, log-space). Actual width = exp(d) * sd(x). d = 0 gives descending width equal sd(x). par[5] (e) Initial selectivity (real line, logit-space). Transformed via 1 / (1 + exp(-e)), e = 0 gives initial selectivity 0.5, large negative values give ~0, large positive values give ~1. par[6] (f) Final selectivity (real line, logit-space). transform e.

title: Double-normal selectivity as a function of length (SS3 pattern 24, full form) — sel_double_normal
text: Numeric vector selectivity values [0, 1].

title: Double-normal selectivity as a function of length (SS3 pattern 24, full form) — sel_double_normal
text: full form implemented (e f active). simplified forms e <= -999 f <= -999 supported.

what: Logistic selectivity as a function of length — sel_logistic
title: Logistic selectivity as a function of length — sel_logistic
text: Logistic selectivity function length

title: Logistic selectivity as a function of length — sel_logistic
Logistic selectivity as a function of length — sel_logistic
text: len Numeric vector length-bin midpoints. par Numeric vector length 6 containing selectivity parameters. first two entries used: par[1] () par[2] (b). inflection point real line, transformed via mean(len) + * sd(len), = 0 gives inflection mean(len). b log-scale 95% width, transformed via exp(b) * sd(len), b = 0 gives 95% width equal sd(len).

title: Logistic selectivity as a function of length — sel_logistic
text: Numeric vector selectivity values (0, 1].
